See below, n. 19. In this case the name of his son and some clearly Jewish formula on the bowl suggest that this man (who is cursed in the bowl) was Jewish. For the name Zutra see under S-H/M.

According to CAMIBBM this name means “black,” see above, n. 1, and is therefore intended to “blacken” the character of Zutri, against whom this incantation was written. CAMIBBM also maintains that Zutra means “small” and the entire combination is derogatory. However, the title “Mar” that this person carries (see Introduction 6.6.1.1) and the provenance of both name and patronyme in rabbinic literature may militate against this assumption. On the other hand, the presence of this name on three incantations bowls in the British Museums, and one in the Louvre, may support this conjecture.
See above, n. 11.

The bowl scribe uses this name to adjure and seal demons and spirits. His role resembles that of יהושע בן פרחיה who is a historical Jewish sage who acquired over time magical qualities, see Introduction 6.7.1. We know nothing of an ערבדזיוא בר רבי, but he too may be a fictional magician.

For the names on the incantation bowls as Iranian see Introduction 1.4.1. This Iranian prefix is recorded in the Bible as ארתחשסתא (e.g. Ezra 7:1). The fall of the ח is a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20. The יה suffix is an assimilation to the biblical theophric elements. In Semitic names we often find a move in the opposite direction, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.5.

The word אושפיזא in Sokoloff, DJBA, 98, is identified as of Middle Persian origin, and denoting ‘host.’

For the names on the incantation bowls as Iranian see Introduction 1.4.1. Under names beginning with Afrandad, Justi, INB, 5-6, refers the reader to names beginning with Fra and Phra or Fer. דוך (Dūχt) is usually a feminine suffix (daughter), see Introduction 2.4.1. In this case, however, it seems clear that the person on this incantation bowl is male, thus I assume this is a scribal error, and the scribe intended to write אפירדד, Dad being the Iranian suffix for gift, see Introduction 2.4.1. This is my suggested interpretation of the text that reads: הרמסדר טרדי. I assume the scribe forgot to insert a בן or בר (son). I cannot imagine that טרדי is the second name of הרמסדר because the former is female, as its appearance at the beginning of this bowl indicates (טרדי בת אוני) and the latter is male, as the other appearances of this name in this corpus indicate. I assume that the bowl was written to protect both mother (טרדי בת אוני) and son (הרמסדד [בר] טרדי).

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. This bowl is divided into three distinctive texts. In the first (p. 16) a certain סתוס son of Numenis is mentioned. In the second (p. 18) this son of Numenis is mentioned and in the third (p. 20) a סתוס son of Numenis is mentioned three times with variations of the name. The editor thought all five could either be explained as a variations of the same name or five different people. I think there is a third possibility, namely that in each part of the bowl a different brother is mentioned.

Th bowl is divided into three distinctive texts. In the first (p. 16) a certain סתוס (Satius) son of Numenis is mentioned. Boyce, “Ayādgār ī Zar Ran: Memorial of Zarēr: Short Pahlavi Text which is the Only Surviving Specimen in that Language of Ancient Iranian Epic Poetry,”Encyclopedia Iranica(1987), http://www.iranica.com/articles/ayadgar-i-zareran.

Abda is a common Iranian prefix, see Justi, INB, 1. As suggested to me (see Introduction 1.4) the name was also known in Arabic (ʿAbd-Allāh – عبد الله) and in Hebrew (ʿAbdi – עבדי), but the name of the person in this list was written with an initial א and his name was found on an incantation bowl, see Introduction 1.4.1.

For Iranian names with the prefix Ādhur/Ādūr/̓Αδώρ see Justi, INB, 5. Ādhur is one of the three holy fires of the Zoroastrians, see Introduction 1.4.

It was emphasized to me that this may be an Aramaic name deriving from “black,” see Introduction 1.4.

This is IJO 3’s suggestion as to how to read this name (p. 193). Although the element Mithr is well documented in Justi, INB, 204-6, the rest of the name cannot be identified with any known form.

Iranian, Justi, INB, 241. Although the Greek names Πάππος / Παπίας also exist (see under G/M), I am certain all these Babylonian rabbis, who readily chose from the Iranian name pool, were thinking of this Iranian name. Since Iranian is an Indo-European language, Pāpā here, like in Greek and other European languages, means “male ancestor” (father/grandfather).
